repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fix #30763

This is my first time contributing to this project, so how do i add test case coverage to the pr ?

comment_data.body: nearly identical to `write_blob`. can we parameterize `write_blob` instead of copy-pasting it
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1393,6 +1393,35 @@ static bool write_blob(FileDescriptor *const fp, const blob_T *const blob)
   return false;
 }
 
+/// Write a String to file with descriptor `fp`.
+///
+/// @param[in]  fp  File to write to.
+/// @param[in]  data String to write.
+///
+/// @return true on success, or false on failure.
+
+static bool write_string(FileDescriptor *const fp, const char *const data)

comment_data.body: I have create a `write_data` function which will accept `char*` from `write_string` or `write_blob` and then `write_data` will write to the file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1393,6 +1393,35 @@ static bool write_blob(FileDescriptor *const fp, const blob_T *const blob)
   return false;
 }
 
+/// Write a String to file with descriptor `fp`.
+///
+/// @param[in]  fp  File to write to.
+/// @param[in]  data String to write.
+///
+/// @return true on success, or false on failure.
+
+static bool write_string(FileDescriptor *const fp, const char *const data)

comment_data.body: The other types are still disallowed. Please only remove `'"test"'`, keeping the others and adjusting the expected error message.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -148,12 +148,6 @@ describe('writefile()', function()
       'Vim(call):E118: Too many arguments for function: writefile',
       pcall_err(command, ('call writefile([], "%s", "b", 1)'):format(fname))
     )
-    for _, arg in ipairs({ '0', '0.0', 'function("tr")', '{}', '"test"' }) do
-      eq(
-        'Vim(call):E475: Invalid argument: writefile() first argument must be a List or a Blob',
-        pcall_err(command, ('call writefile(%s, "%s", "b")'):format(arg, fname))
-      )

comment_data.body: Lines in this files are commented out by adding `" ` at the beginning of the line, not removed. Please see other commented out lines in this file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,7 +18,6 @@ func Test_writefile()
   call assert_equal("vimmers", l[4])
   call delete(f)
 
-  call assert_fails('call writefile("text", "Xfile")', 'E475: Invalid argument: writefile() first argument must be a List or a Blob')

@@ -18,7 +18,6 @@ func Test_writefile()
   call assert_equal("vimmers", l[4])
   call delete(f)
 
-  call assert_fails('call writefile("text", "Xfile")', 'E475: Invalid argument: writefile() first argument must be a List or a Blob')

@@ -18,7 +18,6 @@ func Test_writefile()
   call assert_equal("vimmers", l[4])
   call delete(f)
 
-  call assert_fails('call writefile("text", "Xfile")', 'E475: Invalid argument: writefile() first argument must be a List or a Blob')

comment_data.body: This message should not be changed. In Lua a blob *is* a string. And in Vimscript, string is not accepted for this function.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -148,9 +148,9 @@ describe('writefile()', function()
       'Vim(call):E118: Too many arguments for function: writefile',
       pcall_err(command, ('call writefile([], "%s", "b", 1)'):format(fname))
     )
-    for _, arg in ipairs({ '0', '0.0', 'function("tr")', '{}', '"test"' }) do
+    for _, arg in ipairs({ '0', '0.0', 'function("tr")', '{}' }) do
       eq(
-        'Vim(call):E475: Invalid argument: writefile() first argument must be a List or a Blob',
+        'Vim(call):E475: Invalid argument: writefile() first argument must be a List, a Blob or String',

comment_data.body:
Instead of changing writefile to accept `VAR_STRING`, it should continue to only accept `VAR_BLOB`, but it should also check `current_sctx.sc_sid == SID_LUA`.

If `current_sctx.sc_sid == SID_LUA`, then use `vval.v_string` (I think? Or pass `vval.v_blob` and treat it as a string).

If that doesn't work, then possibly the "bridge" somewhere may need to either...

- special-case writefile when called from Lua
- convert all Lua calls to "blob". or maybe a list of certain functions.
I think adding an additional `&& current_sctx.sc_sid == SID_LUA` here is enough. `vval.v_blob` is not valid when `v_type` is `VAR_STRING`.
neovim crashes when i add this && current_sctx.sc_sid == SID_LUA ?
Ah, not here. Near the error message above.

This doesn't work, as the error message is shown on both branches. Also according to @justinmk there is no need to use two different error messages. So keep the original error message and just change the `(argvars[0].v_type != VAR_BLOB)` condition to `(argvars[0].v_type != VAR_BLOB && !(argvars[0].v_type == VAR_STRING && current_sctx.sc_sid == SID_LUA))`.

comment_regular_data.body: Thanks for working on this. Test coverage should probably go in `test/functional/vimscript/writefile_spec.lua`. Adding a testcase there should not prove to be too difficult if you look at the pre-existing tests.

> how do i add test case coverage to the pr ?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md links to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/README.md#running-tests
other than string , blob or list where should the write test fail, i have removed tests that were passing lists, dicts, blobs as string, so those will become redundant now.

> other than string , blob or list where should the write test fail, i have removed tests that were passing lists, dicts, blobs as string, so those will become redundant now.

Why? Checks for invalid types should be tested.

> > other than string , blob or list where should the write test fail, i have removed tests that were passing lists, dicts, blobs as string, so those will become redundant now.
> 
> Why? Checks for invalid types should be tested.

Those are basically strings right and the test cases where checking if lists, dicts were passed as string, but now strings are accepted

> > > other than string , blob or list where should the write test fail, i have removed tests that were passing lists, dicts, blobs as string, so those will become redundant now.
> > 
> > 
> > Why? Checks for invalid types should be tested.
> 
> Those are basically strings right and the test cases where checking if lists, dicts were passed as string, but now strings are accepted

You are confusing the two arguments. Only strings are accepted for the second argument, both before and after the second PR. And for the first argument, there are still types that are not accepted.

> You are confusing the two arguments. Only strings are accepted for the second argument, both before and after the second PR. And for the first argument, there are still types that are not accepted.

oh got it, i will add the test case back to it

I thought about this a bit more. Although this change makes sense for Lua, it leads to inconsistencies with other Vim script functions. For example, in `setline()`, `\n` is translated to `\0` both when passing a single string and when passing a list of strings. However, here in `writefile()` this is only done when passing a list of strings, not when passing a single string.

Of course, `setline()` doesn't accept a blob, but this makes me wonder whether it's better to add a more general way to allow explicitly distinguishing between Vimscript blobs and strings in Lua (that also works for variables instead of only function arguments, like how `vim.empty_dict()` distinguishes between an empty dict and an empty list).

> but this makes me wonder whether it's better to add a more general way to allow explicitly distinguishing between Vimscript blobs and strings in Lua

Not really in favor of adding this distinction on the Lua side. Lua shouldn't have to care about blobs at all.

> For example, in `setline()`, `\n` is translated to `\0` both when passing a single string and when passing a list of strings.

When calling `setline(string)` from Lua, let's treat it as blob? Could make this a general rule.

> > For example, in `setline()`, `\n` is translated to `\0` both when passing a single string and when passing a list of strings.
> 
> When calling `setline(string)` from Lua, let's treat it as blob? Could make this a general rule.

That seems even more complicated, and not backward-compatible.

I think `setline()` is irrelevant as context mandates it must be a _single_ line, so only NUL:s make sense, not interpreting `\n` as `\n`

> However, here in writefile() this is only done when passing a list of strings, not when passing a single string.

This should be completely fine for `writefile()`. There is already countless examples of vim script functions which are inconsistent with themselves and with other vim script functions. Like `setreg()` with a string _already_ behaves like this PR does for `writefile()`. 

In the end, for `writefile()` we are changing an **error** into an actual behavior, so we can just pick whatever behavior makes sense for us. Worrying about vimL self-consistency is the mind-killer.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(eval): allow writefile() to accept strings
